utterances: Absolutely, and I think, you know, in this economy today, we couldn't ask for a better time to learn how to budget money.
So why not start now?
The sacrifices that are involved, yeah, all right, there's not all that many people I don't think who take mom and dad's money and go for a spree at Gucci.
But you do describe...
But you'd be surprised.
Well, I might be.

But you did describe a friend who said, you know, it would mean the difference between living in Manhattan, which is very expensive, or moving to Brooklyn or Queens, considerably less fashionable, a long ride on the subway if you want to get to work.
Right, and there are some people that just aren't willing to make that sacrifice.
And that's fine if you wanted to stay in Manhattan, find a way to make it work.
I mean, I am not telling you need to move out of Manhattan, but certainly if you want a certain lifestyle, you should try to achieve on your own.
Let's get Amber on the line.
Amber with us from Monroe in Michigan.
Hi, How are you?
Very well, thank you.
I am calling because my sister and I have opposite experiences.
I put myself through college with scholarships and whatnot, and my parents completely subsidized her life through college.
And it works out great.
I mean, we are both adults, and we both have our own lives now.
But it has worked out OK for both of us.
So I am not sure that it's a terrible thing, and I am 29 and she's 24.
I was going to say that you seem to be the older one.
I am.
And there had to have been a moment, maybe, just a fleeting moment, of resentment over the differences the way two situations played out.
Mostly for me, it was interesting.
I have two children, and I was much busier raising my children and trying to maintain my scholarships than to be irritated with my sister because I needed her to lean on for support.
I wasn't talking about being irritated with your sister so much as your parents.
No, I'm not sure that it wouldn't have gotten me anywhere, so - and then my sister would not have been as successful as she is.
So it just would brought things down instead of - it would have been a waste of energy on my part.
So no one has suffered on this?
I don't think so.
I really don't.
Well, interesting.
A win-win situation.
Thanks for the call, Amber.
That's interesting.
I wonder if that was a choice for her to put herself through or how that all worked out.
Well, it also may have been a financial - I should have kept her on the line and asked her.
I apologize for that.
Anyway, let's get Rob on the line.
Rob's calling us from Miami.
Hi, I am just calling because I am 24-year-old student, you know, post-college student, and I have student loans to pay off.
And in today's society, you know, 30 is the new 20.
We are not living in the society today where most people think of 18 you are out the door, it's over.
You know, college is 50,000 plus dollars a year if you go to a private school.
It's a huge burden of responsibility to put on somebody when they graduate college, you have to be paying off those loans.
You know, 500 sometimes, a thousand dollars a month.
You know, if you didn't finance it right, which a lot of people who take out student loans without the help of their parents have to do, and you know, the parents want to help out.
I think it's the parents' choice, and then you write columns such as this, that you know, somebody's parents might read, and they get all worried that they are doing the wrong thing for their child.
And all of the sudden, you know, they get cut off because they start second guessing their decision.
And then the child is left, you know, high and dry.
There's that annoyance we are looking for.
And in California, undocumented workers without insurance.
But perhaps the biggest question raised by the proposed guidelines is who will pay for treatment if those HIV cases are identified.
Let's see if we can get another song in with theâ€¦
That's OK.
I understand where you are coming from.
I think student loans, I think, are separate from paying someone's rent, paying someone's utilities, giving them extra money on the side.
The way I've always thought and the way I've been brought up is that, you know, parents are there if they can to help put you through school.
And I understand that that's a huge burden.
But then, there are other places you can make sacrifices so that you are able to pay off as much as you can every month.

I don't know that I agree with the 30 is the new 20 in the sense that if we keep saying things like that, then, you know, then 40 will become the new 20 and then when are we ever taking responsibility for ourselves?
I mean, the average age of marriage today is, I believe, 32 years old, before it was 19 years old.
Obviously, the generation gap has changed, and the way we are raised is differently.
You know, you call them I guess helicopter hoverparents but what's wrong with the help of the parents if they are willing to provide it?

I'm not saying that they should pay every bill that you have, but if they want to throw you, you know, half your month's rent and help you build a savings because they can, what's wrong with the fact that when I hit 30, I'm going to have a savings thanks to my parents, and I am going to be able to back off to them when I am ready to back off to them.
But that's the question, will you be able to?

I mean, that's where I foresee the problem is, you know, when you get to that age, is it that easy to just say, well, I have gotten support for you for the last 30 years, and now I am on my own, and I am a 100 percent willing to be on my own.
I think that most people at some point break off from the parents, but I think that, you know, that's a decision between the parent and the child.
And when you write columns like this, it kind of screws up the mental thoughts of a parent.
Well listen, everyone can parent how they want to parent, I am not here to tell them how, I am just, you know, making commentary based on my experience and friends so...
I commend you, I commend you for going to New York and living on your own.
I think that's a great thing.
Well, you know, I think that's just - you have to take in consideration other people's, you know.
Absolutely.
Rob, good luck with the student loans.
Thanks a lot.
All right.
Thanks very much for the call.

We are talking with Melody Serafino who wrote an article in this week's issue of Newsweek magazine about college graduates who are supported financially by their parents through adulthood she said, begins with financial independence.
You are listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And let's go to Jameson (ph).
Jameson with us from Salem in Oregon.
Hi, I like what I hear.
I am a parent of five kids.
My oldest is almost 17, and I count it as my great responsibility to train them to be adults, to train them to be independent of me.
I am very involved in their lives.
We home school.
They work for me.

You know, not all of them yet but, I mean this is the vision that we are promoting, is, we are not cutting them loose now to let the world guide them or media culture guide them or the public schools to guide them.

We are wanting to train them not to extend their childhood or adolescence into their thirties, but to train them to be responsible adults so that when they graduate from high school, then they can negotiate some issues here.
Do they want more education?
Do they want to help us pay rent?
Do they just want to work more?
Do they want to do mission work?
And we are going to help support that?
Either way, we expect them to be responsible adults when they graduate from high school.
All right.
Jameson, thanks for the call.
I think that you're driving, so be careful out there, OK.
I am, thank you.
All right.
Thanks very much for the phone call.
And let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
Philip (ph).
Philip with us from Columbia, South Carolina.
How are you doing there, sir?
All right.
You know, I think your parents or whoever can kind of step in and help you if they feel that this is the correct thing is the right thing to do.
And you know, I fell on my face on my first career.
And I had to redirect.
And you know, I headed up moving back into the house twice.

And from that point, I (unintelligible) myself out and became a senior vice president of a large financial institution, but if my parents weren't there to help me, I was, in two situations, where I was going to end up on the street.
I am not sure that that's what Melody was talking about.

Not the situation where as you say you fell flat on your face and needed to move back into your home, but the situation where you are out on your own and, you know, a lifestyle you probably could not otherwise afford is subsidized by your parents.
Yeah, go ahead, please.
Oh, no I'm sorry.
I think yours is sort of an extreme situation where maybe at that point in your life that's who you had to turn to, and I don't see a problem with that necessarily.

What I see a problem with these kids who, or young people who can be on their own and can afford to be on their own and are perfectly capable of making those decisions, and you know, in a circumstance where they are able to make those decisions on their own, and yet are still going back to their parents for every little financial need.
Yeah.

Well, they shouldn't be doing that at all but, you know, they have to decide the second time if, you know, they are going to allow me to come back, or here I am kind of in limbo like I've got no money in the bank, I've got no credit, I've got nowhere to go.
And finally they kind of stood up and said come on back and now I've restarted my career and redirected and I', am a millionaire now.
I hope some of that money is going back to your parents.
Well, I do contribute to NPR, and I do help take care of my mother.
All right, Philip.
Thanks very much for the phone call and appreciate it, and let's hope that was the last time you have to move back in.
Things are very well now.
Thanks.
All right.
Bye bye.
And Melody Serafino, we appreciate your time today, too.
